qas.question: Where did the word Tajik come from?

answers.text: the name of a pre-Islamic (before the seventh century A.D.) tribe

qas.question: Why is it hard to find the origin of the word Tajik?

answers.text: because the term is "embroiled in twentieth-century political disputes about whether Turkic or Iranian peoples were the original inhabitants of Central Asia."

qas.question: Which country's name means "Land of the Talks"?

plausible_answers.text: to definitively state the origins of the word "Tajik"

qas.question: According to the Library of Congress's 1987 Country Study of Tajikistan, what is difficult?
The original inhabitants of Central Asia were either Indian or who?
What is most likely the name of a pre-Indian tribe?

context: <b4_0>Tajikistan<b4_0/> means the <a0_0>"Land of the Tajiks"<a0_0/>. The suffix "-<b7_0>stan<b7_0/>" (Persian: ـستان‎‎ -stān) is Persian for <a1_0>"place of" or "country"<a1_0/> and <b8_0>Tajik<b8_0/> is, most likely, <a2_0>the name of a pre-Islamic (before the seventh century A.D.) tribe<a2_0/>. According to the Library of Congress's 1997 Country Study of Tajikistan, it is difficult <b5_0>to definitively state the origins of the word "Tajik"<b5_0/> <a3_0>because the term is "embroiled in twentieth-century political disputes about whether <b6_0>Turkic<b6_0/> or Iranian peoples were the original inhabitants of Central Asia."
